three days later after being sent to same place

timeline.subject: Procureur d'office
timeline.details: Procureur d'office for Prior and monks of St Epvre at Toul orders investigation into Catherine Malgrais

timeline.subject: Catherine Malgrais
timeline.details: First interrogation; she denied all charges

timeline.subject: Catherine Malgrais
timeline.details: Confrontations with witnesses; deadlock with no movement

timeline.subject: Catherine Malgrais
timeline.details: Procureur d'office (Sr. Handel) requests torture (ordinaire et extraordinaire)

timeline.subject: Catherine Malgrais
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture; initially denied, then confessed 2 hours later to executioner

timeline.subject: Catherine Malgrais
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves death sentence

timeline.subject: Catherine Malgrais
timeline.details: Formal death sentence by court at Champegnoult

timeline.subject: Catherine Malgrais
timeline.details: Execution carried out same day as sentencing

notable_quotes.speaker: Sr. Philippe George
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle prenne tesmoignage de tels propos cy dessus sy elle estoit femme de bien sur quoy elle prevenue respondit n'avoir assez de moyen pour le faire
notable_quotes.english: that she take testimony of such words if she was a woman of honor, to which she replied she did not have enough means to do so
notable_quotes.context: Philippe George called her witch, accused her of killing his father and sister

notable_quotes.speaker: Catherine Malgrais (threat to Nicolas Warin's wife)

notable_quotes.context: Catherine stroked horse before it fell ill and died

notable_quotes.speaker: Catherine Malgrais during torture
notable_quotes.english: she would damn her soul if she admitted to being a witch

His sister-in-law (implied relationship through Nicolas Warin)
he and his wife had quarrelled
her previous husband, Jean la Tresse

economic_context.details: Multiple disputes involving labor agreements (ploughing), borrowed items (horse, hay, goat), property damage (pear tree cut down), and debts (6 gros). Witness testimony noted Catherine 'had means' but did not pursue legal action when publicly called witch. Another witness reported Catherine and husband 'did not have much property.' Marriage inquiry revealed concerns about their economic status.

Told Catherine that witness said she was always spying to hear if people talked about her
Marriage inquiry and subsequent report back to Catherine
Father's fall from hayloft would have been attributed to Catherine had she been reputed witch at that time (18 years earlier)

emotional_state_notes: During torture said she would damn her soul if she admitted being witch
Appeared to lose consciousness during strappado - 'en extaze sans vouloir parler aulcun mot'
Had to be awoken 'comme d'ung sommeil'
Two hours after torture told executioner she was ready to confess rather than endure more

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Said Margueritte wife of Didier Grand Didier had tried to strangle her previous husband Jean la Tresse (Margueritte admitted violent quarrel but denied violence)
Alleged thefts of flax and grain against Nicolas Perey (he denied strongly)

extraction_metadata.notes: Very detailed trial record with 15 witnesses providing extensive testimony. Notable for the sheer volume of alleged harms (primarily animal deaths following quarrels), the accused's repeated claim she lacked means to pursue legal redress when publicly defamed, and the role of the procureur d'office (Sr. Handel) whose own cow had allegedly been killed by the accused. Catherine maintained innocence under extreme torture until losing consciousness, then confessed 2 hours later. Trial shows classic malefice pattern: quarrel/refusal followed by harm. Economic tensions evident throughout. Judges noted discrepancy between Catherine's claimed age (70) and appearance (under 50, 'forte et robuste').
